I love photography .
I had an older camera that was simply a point and shoot camera .
I bought a nikon coolpix 4300 .
I fell in love with this camera, it combines ease of use , with an immense amount of options and power .
I fell in love with this camera, it combines ease of use , with an immense amount of options and power .
You can use the scene modes , or fine tune the options , you can change the iso level , shutter speed , etc.
This camera is ideal for people who want more power , but don't want to spend 1000s dollars on a camera .
I bought coolpix 4300 two months after I had bought canon powershot s400
Reason for two ?
It was not easy sharing one with my teen age kid
The two cameras are very similar in functionality and pricing
I've had no problem with canon whatsoever
With nikon, although picture qualities are as good as any other 4 mp cameras, I've had the following headaches
Pictures won't transfer to pc directly from the camera using the included transfer cable .
I did everything i could , and it took many days of frustration before concluding that the only way to transfer to pc is with the card reader .
Card reader is included .
The speed is noticeably slower than canon, especially so with flashes on
With low battery, it twice wiped out the entire pictures in the memory chip
I used lexar 256 mb and I still use it which means nothing is wrong with lexar
Be very careful when the battery is low and make sure to carry extra batteries
all the good things about this camera
there are certain issues might be they are to me here - all of them are minor
This camera keeps on autofocussing in auto mode with a buzzing sound which can't be stopped
Would be really good if they have given an option to stop this autofocussing
its only through their software 'nikon view' which reads the images date; time from the images meta-data
So if you use your card reader; copy images - you got to once again open them through their software to put the date; time
there isn't a direct way to add date; time - you got to say 'print images' to a different directory in which there is an option to specify the date; time
Even the slightest of the shakes totally distorts your image
Images taken indoor weren't so clear
You got to have flash 'on' to get it even though your room is well lit
Lens cap is really annoying
Go; get a high speed like lexar 12x or higher cf card
Else with simpler viking cf cards, it takes couple of seconds to write a picture with approximately 'fine' picture quality
The movie clips taken will always have some 'noise' in it - you can't avoid that
overall this is a good camera with a 'really good' picture clarity; an exceptional close-up shooting capability
overall this is a good camera with a 'really good' picture clarity
I would rate this is 4.5 stars picture quality; image size defined above are specific to nikon coolpix
there are problems with my menu dial knob
It became stucked which makes it almost impossible to switch between modes
I send my camera to nikon for servicing , took them a whole 6 weeks to diagnose the problem
they claim that it's some kind of internal damage and refuse to cover the cost via warranty
They wouldn't repair my camera unless if i pay $100 for parts and labor
It is a good camera in terms of the function and quality
nikon absolutely sucks when it comes to customer service
Got a 'system error' problem 30 days after purchase
Made the camera totally inoperable
the lens cap design is flawed
You have to manually take the cap off in order to use it
Audio on video also lacking
it takes very good pictures
shutter delay isn't so bad either
Still, had to send it back to nikon for repair
I am an amateur photographer and here is a piece of advise to all the folks who are thinking about making a move the digital world .
Nikon 4300 is the best camera out there for the features and price .
Here were my requirements in a digital camera :
and I wanted some really great 8x10" photos once in a while
I did not want a very small camera as it seems to get lost in my hands and I wasn't comfortable with that .
I wanted a decent sized camera with a contour for my fingers to hold it steadily.
while giving me an option to use my photography skills by turning on the manual settings .
because I had bought an expensive camcorder before but hadn't used it much
Depending on all the above requirements, I had narrowed down my search to Nikon 4300 and Canon Powershot S400 models .
Nikon got the final nod for its settings auto and manual along with movie modes , medium; compact size , price , brand name , good software that is included and previous reviews
Nikon got the final nod for its settings auto and manual along with movie modes , medium; compact size , price , brand name , good software that is included and previous reviews

I should say I have been very happy with my decision ever since .
The pictures are absolutely amazing - the camera captures the minutest of details .
Pictures taken in an indoor setting are a little dull and rarely hazy if you tend to take photographs from a distance .
Pictures taken in an indoor setting are a little dull and rarely hazy
and I have seen people becoming a little impatient waiting for the flash to glow.
The pictures come out hazy if your hands shake even for a moment during the entire process of taking a picture .
All the above, I think, are problems with all the digital cameras out there and so I have no major complaints .
Try to buy a tripod and that should solve some of those problems .

Over all a fantastic very compact camera, which made us experience photography on a totally new level

let's start with my needs: 1 $500 budget
2 4mp resolution
3 optical clarity and color
4 fast - very little shutter lag
5 compact size
6 good camera grip to minimize camera shake
For three months, I've researched the internet and magazines
And I finally settled on the nikon coolpix 4300
this camera has exceeded my expectations
The daylight pictures are brilliant
the indoor shots are very good
The shutter lag is on par with what I've experienced
the next frame advance is about a couple seconds
Uploading the images to my windows-based pc is very fast and simple
indoor shots from a distance > 8ft lack contrast and color
i'm researching for an inexpensive slave flash unit
The battery life seems to be on the short side but adequate for most situations
I got 45 outdoor and 15 indoor shots with the monitor on
before the battery died
An extra for a back-up battery would be a good investment
The picture editing software it came with is adequate, but not very robust
I'll still use my photosuite for editing
many of the reviews knocked this camera for low light focusing
the focusing was just fine
i love this camera and would whole-heartedly recommend this to anyone wanting a high quality point and shoot camera
i still love this camera

allows the use of filters

Here's what you may miss or be annoyed by with this camera
No direct firewire to the camera
There is usb, though
The camera is so small that when you attach some lenses the optical viewfinder is partially obscured
You just have to use the lcd viewfinder to see the whole picture .
It's no problem for me personally
Battery has to be removed to recharge .
An ac adapter for powering the camera while the battery's out is not included
Two different adapters -- ur-e 4 and ur-e 7 -- are required for some attachment lenses
Most of these 'annoyances', though, are comparable to what you'll find on other cameras in this price range

Overall the nikon 4300 is a very dependable, robust, and useful little camera.
